text: Fecal transplants can cure severe gut infections by introducing healthy bacteria from a donor.
The appendix isn't useless — it serves as a safe house for beneficial gut bacteria.
Humans can survive with only half a brain — children who have a hemisphere removed can lead normal lives.
The world record for holding one's breath underwater is over 24 minutes.
Laughter actually is good medicine — it reduces stress hormones and boosts immune function.
Your body produces about 1 gram of new red blood cells every hour, totaling 2.4 million per second.
The left lung is smaller than the right to make room for the heart.
Fever is actually your body fighting infection — the elevated temperature helps kill pathogens.
You're taller in the morning than at night because gravity compresses your spinal discs throughout the day.
Humans are the only animals that blush — Darwin called it 'the most peculiar and most human of all expressions.'
The human body contains enough carbon to make 900 pencils, enough fat to make 7 bars of soap, and enough iron to make a 3-inch nail.
Bone marrow transplants can change a person's blood type permanently.
Maggot therapy is still used in modern medicine to clean wounds by eating dead tissue.
The brain can't feel pain because it has no pain receptors — that's why brain surgery can be done while awake.
Humans lose about 30,000 to 40,000 dead skin cells every minute.
The placebo effect works even when patients know they're taking a placebo.
Your body has enough DNA to stretch from the sun to Pluto and back 17 times.
Some people are born without fingerprints due to a rare genetic condition called adermatoglyphia.
The average person produces enough saliva in their lifetime to fill two swimming pools.
Hiccups serve no known beneficial purpose and are likely an evolutionary leftover from our amphibian ancestors.
Your sense of smell is closely linked to memory because the olfactory bulb is part of the brain's limbic system.
The cornea is the only part of the body with no blood supply — it gets oxygen directly from the air.
Goosebumps are a vestigial response — our ancestors' hair would fluff up to appear larger or for insulation.
The average human body contains about 0.2 milligrams of gold, mostly in the blood.
Earwax is technically a type of sweat.
Your bones are constantly being broken down and rebuilt — you have an entirely new skeleton about every 10 years.
The strongest muscle in the body relative to its size is the masseter (jaw muscle).
Humans share 50% of their DNA with bananas.
Newborns don't have kneecaps — they develop between ages 3 and 5.
Your tongue print is as unique as your fingerprint.
Stomach acid is strong enough to dissolve metal, but the stomach lining replaces itself every few days.
Crying releases stress hormones and produces pain-killing endorphins, which is why you feel better after a good cry.
The human body glows with bioluminescence, but it's too faint for our eyes to see.
When you blush, your stomach lining also turns red.
The focusing muscles in your eyes move about 100,000 times a day.
Synesthesia causes some people to taste words or see sounds as colors.
The only organ that named itself is the brain.
Human teeth are as strong as shark teeth.
You lose most of your body heat through your head because it has many blood vessels close to the surface, not because the brain needs cooling.
Astronauts' hearts become more spherical in space because they don't have to pump against gravity.
The human heart creates enough pressure to squirt blood 30 feet.
Babies are born with about 300 bones, but adults only have 206 because many fuse together.
The acid in your stomach is strong enough to dissolve zinc, yet the stomach constantly produces new mucus lining.
Your blood vessels, if laid end to end, would circle the Earth 2.5 times — about 100,000 km.
Wisdom teeth are becoming less common — about 35% of people now never develop them.
Humans are the only animals that produce emotional tears.
Your nose can remember 50,000 different scents.
The liver is the only organ that can completely regenerate itself.
Humans can distinguish about 10 million different colors.
The hardest substance in the human body is tooth enamel.
